text: Hmm... there MUST be people. I'm wondering if Lindsay Gordon would be a good fit. She's in the SF Bay Area and used to working with people in tech. I'm not sure if it's as specific as B2B marketing but she might be worth reaching out to. <https://www.alifeofoptions.com>. Curious if anyone else is recommended!

text: Broad question here: *When did you know it was time to leave your last company?*

elements.text: Broad question here:
When did you know it was time to leave your last company?

text: When my manager started WhatsApp calling me at 9 PM everyday for a week. :man-shrugging:

elements.text: When my manager started WhatsApp calling me at 9 PM everyday for a week.

text:
If the question is, "when did I know?" it's when I (a) saw an pattern of toxic behavior from my boss that cascaded through the entire company and (b) when I realized the boss had no interest in addressing the behavior.

If the question is, "when did I leave?" the answer is 6 months later. :see_no_evil:

elements.text:

If the question is, "when did I leave?" the answer is 6 months later.

text: i once stayed at a job for ~18 months that i should have left in month 1. my boss encouraged me to buy a car that i couldn’t afford to incentive me to work harder. i was too young and lacked the confidence to flick him off and walk away

elements.text: i once stayed at a job for ~18 months that i should have left in month 1. my boss encouraged me to buy a car that i couldn’t afford to incentive me to work harder. i was too young and lacked the confidence to flick him off and walk away

text: I had conversations about my goals and ambitions with my manager, and even interviewed for another internal role to align with those. Though everyone seemed supportive, I was eventually told that it would take at least a year, maybe 2 years. That actually wasn't a horrible timeframe, but I had a CEO recruiting me at the time, had similar conversations, and he said I could do all the things I wanted to do pretty much Day 1. I mulled over the decision for about a week before deciding to take the new role.

text: Asked for a promotion and showed my impact in the past 2 years, didn't get it. Interviewed elsewhere, got the promotion and a 25% pay raise.

elements.text: Asked for a promotion and showed my impact in the past 2 years, didn't get it. Interviewed elsewhere, got the promotion and a 25% pay raise.

text: I left my previous company once I realized the toxic work environment and some colleagues were draining my energy and it became clear I couldn't work properly. It took me a while to realize, so you could say I was late. But honestly, if you are wondering if you should leave or not, then that's also a sign that should give you an answer.

text:
I started thinking about leaving when I realized I wasn’t being compensated appropriately, despite repeated attempts to advocate for myself and working weekends every! single! weekend.

What really pushed me over the edge were interactions that made me realize the work environment was toxic and I wouldn’t be able to change that.

text:
I'd love to get input into the HOW of <https://superpath.co/blog/say-yes-to-start-your-career-say-no-to-advance-it|this article>. I agree with the premise 110% and even love the updated graphic. I talk about this concept (and give credit) ever chance I get. But, I still struggle with it measurably.

If you've started saying "no" to things, and are mid-career, HOW did you decide what to say no to?

this article

text: When the company stopped paying pretty much all of their employees & contractors but still expected them to work as normal…. that’s about the same time I realized working for an early stage startup was not for me :grimacing:

elements.text: When the company stopped paying pretty much all of their employees & contractors but still expected them to work as normal…. that’s about the same time I realized working for an early stage startup was not for me

text: Saying "yes" to too many opportunities and hustling on the back end to deliver has always been both a feature and a bug of my personality, but I'm very much on the right/"late-career" side of that graph now.  Part of the "how" is probably not super instructive: just getting tired over the years.

elements.text: Saying "yes" to too many opportunities and hustling on the back end to deliver has always been both a feature and a bug of my personality, but I'm very much on the right/"late-career" side of that graph now.  Part of the "how" is probably not super instructive: just getting tired over the years.

text:
I say no about as much as I say yes, and the HOW of picking the yes/no isn't totally linear.

The more logical ingredients include:
• Does the client/project/opportunity fit my skills?
• Can I make a legitimate and helpful impact?
• Does the pay fit my income goals?
• Can this advance my skills, reputation, or connections? 
• Can I do this and meet my outside-of-work lifestyle goals?
• Can I maintain it? 
• If yes to all of the above, do I have bandwidth?
Less logical ingredients include:
• the weather
• how stressed I am when the thing surfaces
• when I last had coffee
• level of imposter syndrome that day

text: The other part of "how" for me, when it comes to saying no, is to add a couple of factors to the mix of whatever is being proposed: odds of a home-run, and realistic effort required.  "Wow, nobody's ever built {niche site} before and there's a ton of volume, and it's easy to rank, for like everything" sounds like a great "yes."  But then you start to look at it and think "am I really going to layer 5 blog posts a week to what I'm already doing, and  what's the best case payout, anyway, like $2K/month in affiliate links a couple years from now?"

text: Maybe a better way to say it is to take opportunities offered to you, and force yourself to create a business plan and present it yourself (or, even better, a colleague) to persuade you to do it.

elements.text: Maybe a better way to say it is to take opportunities offered to you, and force yourself to create a business plan and present it yourself (or, even better, a colleague) to persuade you to do it.

text: Aside: That is such a damn good visualization. Right up there with the chasm and Sinek's circle o' why.

text:
My HOW is less scientific and objectively bad. But here goes:

1. Do I feel it in my gut?
2. Do I know/like this person?
3. Does it tie in to anything else I'm already doing?
If it's not 3 for 3, I'm out.

If it's not 3 for 3, I'm out.

text: Growth. The moment you realize you're no longer valued or able to grow, it's time to pursue new opportunities

elements.text: Growth. The moment you realize you're no longer valued or able to grow, it's time to pursue new opportunities

text:
I’ll 100% make career decisions based on HQ climate if I have to be there; I can’t live and be happy in a place with winter, and I’m finally at the point in my career where I don’t feel like I have to be unhappy to be successful.

I also have my goals, and the two primary relevant ones are a specific salary number and to live outside the U.S. at some point. Those keep me focused on saying yes to things that will push me closer to one or both of those and nix the ones that wouldn’t serve.

text: One other thing that’s helped me, at minimum, get better opportunities to say no to is telling people why something is a no and what relevant thing to them might be a yes instead. I use this less from a career journey standpoint and more in the day-to-day but it’s meant that my career is more strategic, focused and fulfilling.

text: After I met my boss' boss, she said a lot of discriminating things to me.

elements.text: After I met my boss' boss, she said a lot of discriminating things to me.

text: When I realized I was being put in a box. And no matter how hard I worked, or how strategically I played the game, I couldn’t shake the perception that I was just a workhorse rather than an “idea man” or an A player.  Put another way: When leaders didn’t see my potential. I’ve noticed this went hand in hand with others taking credit for my work/ideas, a lack of mentorship, and an unengaged direct manager. All bad signs!
